title: What explains recent tech layoffs, and why should we be worried? | Stanford News

last_post.content: "Layoffs do not solve what is often the underlying problem, which is often an ineffective strategy, a loss of market share, or too little revenue. Layoffs are basically a bad decision." https://news.stanford.edu/2022/12/05/explains-recent-tech-layoffs-worried/

A great frame to parse Google's announcement of #Bard with is @pluralistic's recent minting of "enshittification": https://pluralistic.net/2023/01/21/potemkin-ai/#hey-guys

The core proposition is clear from the UI: everyone gets less say except for Google.

title: The Market for Lemons

last_post.content:
'Those who dared speak up were branded "negative" and "haters", no matter how much data they lugged in tow.'

We were also just told we didn't know what we were talking about or didn't know how to write JS enough OR that we didn't work on complex enough applications that warranted needing CSS-IN-JS solutions or going all in on frameworks :) :) :)

https://infrequently.org/2023/02/the-market-for-lemons/

title: We come to bury ChatGPT, not to praise it.

last_post.content:
"We come to bury ChatGPT, not to praise it." Excellent piece by @danmcquillan
https://www.danmcquillan.org/chatgpt.html

I suggest you read the whole thing, but some pull quotes:

"ChatGPT is a part of a reality distortion field that obscures the underlying extractivism and diverts us into asking the wrong questions and worrying about the wrong things."

>>

title: Semantic search answers: Q&A against documentation with GPT3 + OpenAI embeddings

last_post.content:
It looks to me like the Bing implementation is the same pattern that a bunch of other people are trying at the moment: you run a traditional search, then dump the search result summaries into a prompt and get the language model to generate text using those summaries

I tried something similar against my blog a few weeks ago! https://simonwillison.net/2023/Jan/13/semantic-search-answers/

title: Find the human art behind the A.I. images

last_post.content:
The problem with this https://www.stableattribution.com/ (allowing lookup of which artists contributed to a generated image) is it works because Stability (and MidJourney and Hugging Faces diffusion algo) are built on an open source underlying dataset LAION.
Meanwhile those who put their stuff behind closed source / trade secret wall (hello OpenAI, sic) are not open to analysis.

title: Open Review of the Second Half of “After Disruption: A Future for Cultural Memory”

last_post.content:
Starting on revisions to respond to peer reviews of my forthcoming book, After Disruption: A Future for Cultural Memory. For background on the book, you can read the full drafts of it here http://www.trevorowens.org/2022/07/open-review-of-the-second-half-of-after-disruption-a-future-for-cultural-memory/ and here http://www.trevorowens.org/2022/01/open-review-of-the-first-half-of-after-disruption-a-future-for-cultural-memory/

I am planning to add some additional targeted positive examples of cultural memory work/projects/initiatives that model centering an ethic of care, a maintenance mindset, and a focus on repair.

title: naniar Version 1.0.0 | Credibly Curious

last_post.content:
naniar version 1.0.0 is now on CRAN!

This is a 1.0.0 release to signify its publication in JSS - the Journal of Statistical Software. Thank you to @visnut for her continued support and inspiration for the software and the paper

Here's a little bit more info in a blog post:

https://www.njtierney.com/post/2023/02/07/naniar-version-1/

And here's the JSS paper: https://www.jstatsoft.org/article/view/v105i07

#rstats #missingdata #datavis

title: Talking About Large Language Models

last_post.content:
We moeten het hebben over hoe we we het hebben over #AI.

"The more adept LLMs become at mimicking human language, the more vulnerable we become to anthropomorphism, to seeing the systems in which they are embedded as more human like than they really are. This trend is amplified by the natural tendency to use philosophically loaded terms, such as "knows", "believes", and "thinks", when describing these systems."

Great paper by @mshanahan

➡https://arxiv.org/abs/2212.03551

title: eDiff-I: Text-to-Image Diffusion Models with an Ensemble of Expert Denoisers

last_post.content:
eDiff-I: A new text-to-image #diffusion model. Uses T5 and both CLIP encoders for conditioning. Instead of using the same denoising model for all steps, they propose using multiple specialized ones. A 🧵

Paper: https://arxiv.org/abs/2211.01324

Day 11 #30daysofDiffusion #MachineLearning

title: Cards for Ukraine

last_post.content:
Since donations are drying up, figured I mention our little project one more time.

https://cards-for-ukraine.at

We convert donations to €50 food vouchers for Ukrainian families who fled to Austria. We operate zero overhead, and even have a discount contract with a large local grocery chain.

I just finished packaging 260 cards of the last batch. We've sent out about €180.000 worth of vouchers since May 2022.

We're also 100% transparent. All contracts/orders/payments here:
https://drive.google.com/drive/folders/1PxOL8A44bIRU1Hdoq87_2iXSLNmnMXQr

title: SpaceHost

last_post.content:
🥳 HOORAY! 🥳

#SpaceHost is taking applications for early access!

What is #SpaceHost? Fully managed hosting for the Fediverse!

Among the services we will host:

* Mastodon
* Pixelfed
* Calckey
* Lemmy
* Gitea
* and more!

What's more, we'll have your instance up and running within 5 minutes!

@reiver and I have been fast at work on #SpaceHost for months. We want to make running a Fediverse instance super easy peasy!

It will soon be available in closed beta!

https://spacehost.one/

title: Data Explorer: Environmental Impacts of Food

last_post.content:
One for breakfast: Greenhouse gas emissions per kilogram of different milks.

The production of cow’s milk causes the highest emissions – oat milk the lowest.

From our ‘Environmental Impacts of Food Explorer’
https://ourworldindata.org/explorers/food-footprints?facet=none&uniformYAxis=0&Commodity+or+Specific+Food+Product=Specific+food+products&Environmental+Impact=Carbon+footprint&Kilogram+%2F+Protein+%2F+Calories=Per+kilogram&By+stage+of+supply+chain=false&country=Beefburger~Cow%27s+milk~Pizza~Oat+milk~Soy+milk~Almond+milk~Rice+milk

title: How Duolingo’s AI Learns What You Need to Learn

last_post.content:
I write a fair bit about the things at AI/ML is not good at, so I want to acknowledge some of the really amazing use cases.

One seems to be in very specific kinds of education.

I'm very impressed with the capabilities of Duolingo, which I've been using 10-15 hours a week for the past four months.

Here's an interesting article from the Duolingo team about how they use ML to make it such a good learning experience.

https://spectrum.ieee.org/duolingo

title: Inside the “hostile takeover”: an autopsy of the Jan. 31 Board of Trustees meeting

last_post.content: A reminder that student journalism is thriving -- and doing essential work -- even as other local news media wither. Here's an example, from a Florida college that an extremist governor is turning into a right-wing propaganda mill. https://ncfcatalyst.com/inside-the-hostile-takeover-an-autopsy-of-the-jan-31-board-of-trustees-meeting/

title: How I Use RSS To “Rewild” My Attention - Clive Thompson - Medium

last_post.content:
"How I Use RSS To 'Rewild' My Attention"

My essay on the joys of using RSS to follow 400 weird, offbeat, niche blogs and sites that cater to my particular obsessions ...

... and how it helps me find more fascinating, deeper material than I see on algorthmically-sorted-for-virality social media

The piece, for Medium subscribers: https://clivethompson.medium.com/how-i-use-rss-to-rewild-my-attention-7731267a40d8

If you're not a Medium subscriber, here's a "friend" link: https://clivethompson.medium.com/how-i-use-rss-to-rewild-my-attention-7731267a40d8?sk=54d69b1b262db8d3d1a0229ae69816b9

title: New article: Staying with the trouble of networks – KCL Digital Humanities

last_post.content:
How can problems with network practices can be taken as invitations to attend to the diverse settings in which network graphs are created and used?

New article by @jwyg
and @lbngr in our department together with Daniela van Geenen @tommv @jacomyma and Axel Meunier: https://kingsdh.net/2023/02/07/new-article-staying-with-the-trouble-of-networks/

title: https://xai4cv.github.io/

last_post.content:
Join the 2nd Explainable AI for CV (XAI4CV) workshop at #CVPR2023!
https://xai4cv.github.io/

👥 The workshop will take place on June 19th in Vancouver, Canada. More to follow on in-person/hybrid setup

🎤 We have a fantastic line-up of speakers: @qveraliao, Mohit Bansal, Marina M.-C. Höhne (née Vidovic), @arvind, Alice Xiang, and @davidbau

📄 Submit papers and demos by March 14th (proceedings track) and May 19th (non-proceedings track)

title: Atlas

last_post.content:
This new interactive that for exploring 5+ million highly retweeted tweets highlights some interesting features we've been working on at Nomic for exploring large unstructured text and embedding collections. (And the sort of data that will become inaccessible when the Twitter AI is shut off!)

(short thread)
https://atlas.nomic.ai/map/twitter
